The August jobless rate of 5.1 percent was the lowest since 5.0 percent in March 1989, the department said.
The non-farm payroll data are based on a survey of employers and the jobless rate is based on a survey of households.

Wall Street economists expected an August rise in non-farm payrolls of 244,000 and a jobless rate of 5.3 percent. They also had forecast a 0.3 percent gain in August average hourly earnings and an average work week of 34.5 hours.
The household survey also indicated that August employment rose 171,000, that the labor force contracted by 296,000, and the number of unemployed fell 467,000.

Katherine Abraham, Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said some of the drop in unemployment in August may be explained by the late timing of the survey reference week in that month, which likely caused the survey to capture more of the normal seasonal movement out of the labor force at the end of the summer.
However, she said the large drop in the number of unemployed suggests "at least some of the improvement in the unemployment rate is unrelated to the timing of the survey reference period."
